awd_titl_txt: SCC-PG - Prisons Evolving as Connected Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
United States prisons exist in geographically bounded, technologically disconnected communities.  Restrictions on services and isolation from the outside world, including lack of access to digital devices and the internet in prisons, has restricted prisoners’ opportunities for education and healthcare, has limited their future work and career prospects, and has reinforced divisions between incarcerated people and their communities. Recent legislation and the work of many volunteers and organizations is making it possible for correctional institutions to dramatically improve prisoner’s options and opportunities for education, communication, and future well-being. Nonetheless, regardless of delivery model, access to, and training in, a robust technology infrastructure is essential for these opportunities to become a reality.  This project seeks to support technology access and the people impacted by incarceration, with the ultimate goal of fostering their prospects for the future.

With this planning award, the project team is tackling challenges to technology access and use through purposeful community engagement and is drawing on community-based systems dynamics research as a practical and empirical tool to constructively approach system change. Strategically selected focus groups will ensure the project team is addressing systemic factors and their interrelationships based on a variety of prisoners’ and experts’ perspectives and experiences.  A working group is applying these findings in the development of a plan, which will be central to determining the recommendations for an infrastructure that disrupts current dehumanizing systems, supports successful re-entry, and addresses challenging conversations about security and administration. The leadership team will ultimately develop full project to develop and test this infrastructure.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The National Science Foundation (NSF) Smart & Connected Communities Plannig Grant Prisons Evolving as Connected Communities (PEaCC) has engaged diverse community stakeholders to develop a model of prisons as connected communities through the use of carefully designed information and communication technology (ICT). Proposed in 2021, the goal was to ideate such a model that would account for the differening needs, wants, hopes and fears of diverse stakeholders, while also disrupting socio-systemic factors that perpetuate prison systems as contributors to generational and cyclic incarceration; rather the intention was to reposition prisons as equitable habilitative communities supporting successful re-entry and contribution to family and community.

United States prisons constitute a unique geographically and physically bounded, technologically disconnected community. This extreme isolation persists due to dehumanizing narratives around justice-impacted people —narratives closely tied to issues of ability, education, socio-economic
status, race, and ethnicity—and the need to protect the rest of society from them. Unfortunately, this isolation itself contributes to the lack of resources and opportunities inside prisons that would significantly support successful re-entry, in addition to both safer prisons and safer communities. Failure to successfully re-enter society further perpetuates deficit narratives of formerly IP.

The S&CC PEaCC planning grant led by PI Badertscher and co-PI Horowitz--involving organizations including the State University of New York at Buffalo, the New Hampshire Department of Corrections, Princeton Univerisity's Prison Teaching Initiative, The Washington University of St. Louis Prison Education Program, SystemStars, and Education Development Center--used a set of progressive community-based group collaborations to ideate and design a model of prisons as connected communities ultimately represented in the the Principles of Standards of Information and Communication Technology in Prisons. The diverse leadership team spent several months discussing avenues forward, seeking external advice, playing out different scenarios, and engaging either (9) different stakeholder groups to help better illuminate the scope of the problem of ICT in prisons as experienced by the stakeholders in question. These focus groups were Currently Incarcerated People, Formerly Incarcerated People, Wardens and Corrections Staff, Higher Education in Prison Professionals, Re-entry Professionals, Family of Justice-impacted People, Healthcare (physical, mental, & spiritual) Service Providors in prisons, and ICT Professionals. Following the analysis of the focus group data, the leadership team finalized the process of principles and standards development, and then solicited feedback from the external advisory board before launching the next phase.

The next phase of the project involved recruiting and bringing together anoter  diverse set of stakeholders, emphasising the inclusion of those stakeholders most impacted by the issue. The recruitment further focused on six subareas integrally connected to ICT in prisons that emerged as critical in the previous phase. These six areas include: change management, network access & cybersecurity, user-focused technology, community connections, services, and procurement. The area-focused groups, with occassional collaboration with the broader working group, zeroed in on strengths, weaknesses, opportunities and threats of the current system within their focal area to realizing the goal of prisons as rehabilitative connected communities. These groups collaborated using Mural white boards, zoom, and Google tools as the ultimately ideated and proposed the critical ICT principles and standards relative to their focal areas. Once this work was complete, each subgroup identified at least one person to serve on the writing team for the principles and standards.

These selected authors utilized documentation from both the focus groups and the working groups to finalize a set of Principles and Standards to guide the future development of information and communication technology in prisons to ensure prisons were no longer technologically disconnected communities that worsened recidivism, contributed to unsafe communities both inside and outside prison walls, and dehumanized those who lived inside the walls. Rather prisons could be places of habilitation, education, community, growth, and discovery.

What sets this PEaCC process and standards document apart is the significant community involvement, including strong voices of both justice impacted people and corrections staff. It demontrates what can be achieved as diverse communities when we come together to solve problems that impact us all, rather than to ensure our voice dominates. It recognizes and values different perspectives, needs, hopes, and fears, while also illustrating that it is possible to find a way forward.

While the author team, led by PI Badertscher, finalzed these principles and standards, co-PI Horowitz led another subgroup to design the next phase of this work in the form of a Smart and Connected Communities Integrative Research Grant. This new proposal focuses on implementing portions of these principles and standards in two geographically disparate state prison facilities.
